description: Known for housing a famous Beastie Boys sample, the reissue of this 1975 funk and fusion classic brings peerless Polish and American players together for a groovy, eccentric journey.

title: One Nite Alone, The Aftershow: It Ain't Over!
label: NPG
description: Originally released as part of a three-disc set, Prince fires on all cylinders at these live recordings from the early ’00s, a testament to his late-night blues and funk reveries.

title: Killer Road
label: Bella Union
description: Soundwalk Collective is an electronic group featuring vocals by Patti Smith and percussion by her daughter, Jesse. Here, they use field-recordings from Ibiza to rework the poetry of Nico.

title: JEFFERY
label: Atlantic
description: The rap iconoclast returns with his best album since Barter 6, daring and chameleonic, filled with hooks about identity, love, and that undefinable future swag.

title: Trouble
label: Ba Da Bing!
description: Though they’ve been releasing music since the late ’80s, the New Zealand noise trio remain as vital, corrosive, and challenging as ever.

title: The Party's Over EP
label: Caroline
description: The new Rage Against the Machine/Public Enemy/Cypress Hill supergroup is a harmless if not crass experiment that amounts to a bad cover band playing songs they actually wrote.

title: Opalescent
label: Just Music
description: This reissue of the electronic composer’s first album, made in his early 20s, rings thin and hollow compared to the dark genius of his later work.

title: Becoming the Beach Boys: The Complete Hite & Dorinda Morgan Sessions
label: Omnivore
description: A collection of spartan demos, false-starts, and practice runs of early Beach Boys songs recorded in 1961-62 amounts to a curious, often campy origin story for hardcore fans only.

title: Water EP
label: Domino
description: The eight-track Water EP collects preliminary sketches from Aaron Maine’s best album, the spring release Pool. These rudimentary demos are filled with their own attractions and surprises.

title: Prima Donna
label: Def Jam
description: Pushing his versatility, ear for production, and lyricism in new directions, Vince Staples' hot streak continues.

title: Whole & Cloven
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: Bowles has the power to transform the sound of a banjo—and traditional folk music—into something transcendental, often bringing the spirit of Americana to new heights.

title: Amnesty (I)
label: Fiction
description: The first Crystal Castles album without vocalist Alice Glass is also the first safe album from an act that once would have recoiled at such a thought.

title: For this We Fought the Battle of Ages
label: Profound Lore
description: On their fourth full-length, the Salt Lake City doom band SubRosa take inspiration from a 100-year-old dystopian novel about a modern surveillance state. The resulting album is their best yet.

title: Mangy Love
label: Anti-
description: On his eighth album, the singer-songwriter connects his gentle, acerbic soul to his most politically charged, well-stated, and funniest songs.

title: Motion Graphics
label: Domino
description: Joe Williams' first solo project is a breath of fresh air for vaporwave.

title: Things Fall Apart
label: MCA
description: Things Fall Apart was a turning point for the Roots, the record where they figured out what kind of band they could be. Both its themes and its eclectic mix of sounds resonate in the current moment.

title: Larva Lumps and Baby Bumps
label: Artoffact
description: Perennial Long Island noise-rockers return with their first album in 14 years, as detailed and cacophonous as they've always been.

title: Take It, It’s Yours
label: Polyvinyl
description: On this collection of classic punk covers, La Sera’s Katy Goodman and the Hush Sound’s Greta Morgan defang purposefully messy music with honeyed duets and pleasant arrangements.

title: The Bells
label: Studio Barnhus
description: The Swedish producer in charge of bringing capital-F Fun back to the dance floor succeeds in a multitude flying colors across his ebullient and wildly dynamic debut album.

title: Nexus
label: UNO
description: On his sophomore EP, DJ/producer Caleb Halter positions his music between ambient atmospheres and clubby bombast—this time pulling in opposing directions rather than seeking balance.

title: 4th of July
label: Thirty Tigers
description: On his second solo album, the My Morning Jacket guitarist finds comfort in the slow lane of life, eschewing guitar fireworks for easy-chair folk.

title: Ibifornia
label: Love Supreme
description: The French duo resurface with their first album in 10 years, slamming together the Balearic reverie of Ibiza and the pop-chart tank-top vibe of California, not always to great effect.

title: Partners
label: Erased Tapes
description: What starts as an homage to John Cage, soon shifts into an increasingly honest and heartfelt album of solo piano by the young composer.

title: CDW EP
label: self-released
description: The Toronto singer's debut EP arrives fully formed, a short mix of quiet storm R&B and dark pop for doomed lovers.

title: I Told You
label: Interscope
description: On his debut album, the Toronto artist provides his origin story, and proves just how hard it is to escape from the long shadow of Drake.

title: Home Wrecking Years
label: Arts & Crafts
description: On his third solo album, Broken Social Scene’s Brendan Canning offers tentative experiments that ape other bands’ styles. It feels like a guy just filling downtime.

title: Star Core
label: Thrill Jockey
description: On the Bay Area electronic musician’s second solo album, the minutest vibrations are as expressive as the most sweeping gesture. Its mood exquisitely balances melancholy and hope.

title: I.B. Tree
label: self-released
description: With the help of producer I.B. Classic, the Chicago trap-soul rapper delivers the most defining and unifying record of his career.

title: Skiptracing
label: Stones Throw
description: Mild High Club is the solo act of Alex Brettin, a tourmate and disciple of Mac DeMarco’s sunny sound. On his sophomore album, Brettin finds a voice more distinctly his own.

title: Phase Zero
label: Sub Pop
description: On his Sub Pop debut, deranged psych-pop bedroom auteur Morgan Delt cleans up his sound considerably.

title: Blue Rider Songs
label: Scissor Tail
description: On his debut solo album, the Hiss Golden Messenger member finally lets out his voice—a cool, soulful thing filled with deep reverence for the road, if some cynicism about the myths it’s spun.

title: Songs in the Key of Life
label: Motown
description: *Songs in the Key of Life *was the culmination of a historic period of creativity for Stevie Wonder. Its ambition and scope were unprecedented, and he never approached its caliber or impact again.

title: Honor Killed the Samurai
label: Iron Works
description: With his latest, the Brownsville rapper cements himself as a preeminent stylist, his voice hushed but vicious, his production a grim rabbit hole of found sounds, minor keys, and few drums.

title: Rattle
label: Upset the Rhythm
description: The all-drum band Rattle's self-titled record has an admirable sense of freedom and unwillingness to mimic the tropes of conventional songwriting.

title: In Summer
label: Geographic North
description: The experimental ambient musician Jefre Cantu-Ledesma's In Summer is some of the most emotionally evocative noise music of the year.

title: Open Your Eyes
label: Teklife
description: Open Your Eyes, the first set of new tracks released on Teklife's eponymous label, features collaborations with Oneohtrix Point Never and a host of footwork veterans.

title: Spinhead Sessions
label: Goofin'
description: Titled after the studio where the band rehearsed for a movie-soundtracking job, these purely instrumental pieces from 1986 offer another look at the Sonic Youth who had just recorded EVOL.

title: Crappin’ You Negative
label: Fat Possum
description: The mid-'90s Memphis band Grifters wrote songs that sounded like smart conversations you wished you could contribute to, inside jokes you wanted to be let it on. This was their most bracing statement.

title: Paramount
label: Triple B
description: Fury’s debut LP is a proud revival of the Orange County youth crew hardcore tradition. It is a devastating work of emotional and philosophical inquisitiveness that, yes, you can totally punch shit to.

title: Callus
label: Warp
description: Gonjasufi's Callus is an album that's disorienting at its catchiest, harrowing at its ugliest, and more than willing to run both of those modes at the same time.

title: Fishing Blues
label: Rhymesayers
description: The Minneapolis rapper-producer duo Atmosphere over-share on their sloppy and tedious new album, though it still contains a few gripping moments.

title: Boronia
label: Kanine
description: On Boronia, the Australian duo Hockey Dad are a 2016 version of the Wyld Stallyns, if Bill and Ted had been hypnotized by surf rock instead of metal.

title: Official
label: self-released
description: On this new mixtape, Oakland rapper and former Das Racist member Kool A.D. collaborates with the producer Trackademicks to focus on a looming Bay Area influence: hyphy.

title: 5TARB01
label: Endless Xclusive
description: Lexxi worked on Elysia Crampton's excellent July release Demon City. Where Demon City stretched to encompass both past and future, the producer's debut EP* *takes place in a single wide-eyed moment.

title: Jumping the Shark
label: Secretly Canadian
description: The Australian musician Alex Cameron paints quick, affecting character sketches of losers and creeps, bolstered by elementary synth programming and Cameron’s confident, warm baritone.

title: For Mark, Your Son
label: Mello Music Group
description: On his Mello Music debut For Mark, Your Son, the Chicago-born rapper, singer, and producer Lando Chill comes to grips with the death of his father.

title: PARTYNEXTDOOR 3 (P3)
label: Warner Bros.
description: Drake affiliate and OVO signee PARTYNEXTDOOR follows up his biggest hit, penning Rihanna's summer jam “Work,” with his most assured and confident work yet.

title: Convenience
label: Mexican Summer
description: The no-wave inspired Brooklyn punks Pill pair controlled chaos with darkly funny, incisive political commentary.

title: SremmLife 2
label: Interscope
description: SremmLife 2, the follow-up to the turbocharged rap duo's joyous debut SremmLife, is stranger, artsier, and flat-out ballsier than its predecessor.

title: Roosevelt
label: City Slang
description: Roosevelt's debut is a cocktail of disco, French touch, Ibiza house, yacht rock, and electropop that evokes some crowded Tiki-torch dancefloor lost on the Mediterranean coast.

title: Dry
label: Too Pure
description: On her debut, Polly Jean Harvey matched Patti Smith’s incandescence with Bessie Smith’s lasciviousness, outplayed everyone on the British indie circuit, and became an instant star.

title: Kaleidoscope World
label: Flying Nun
description: In early ’80s Dunedin, the Chills were at the forefront of an extraordinary little guitar-pop scene. This reissue of their debut—a major document of their early era—extends the album to 24 tracks.

title: Golden Sings That Have Been Sung
label: Dead Oceans
description: The first song on guitar wunderkind Ryley Walker’s fourth album might be the best thing he’s ever done. Then there are the other seven songs.

title: Daniel Son ; Necklace Don
label: self-released
description: On his third project of 2016, 2 Chainz continues to show the way to rap successfully past the age of 40: He has some of the most enduring, daring, and funny verses in the game.

title: A Weird Exits
label: Castle Face
description: On their latest, Thee Oh Sees show an eagerness to drift away from their foundational ’60s psych-pop and garage-punk roots into more cosmic realms.

label: DFA
description: On their second LP for DFA, Factory Floor’s post-punk past has dissolved into hardware dance pieces of monomaniacal repetition and stiff precision. It’s tirelessly energetic, but often in a brute way.

title: Summer Camp
label: self-released
description: R&B singer/producer theMIND’s debut project Summer Camp is a low-stakes surprise, the late-night stoner’s LP we didn’t know we needed.

title: Live from Trona
label: Carpark
description: Toro Y Moi's Live From Trona is an odd concert album: It was performed in front of no one, amidst the beautiful landscape of Trona—three hours away from Los Angeles.

title: Encore
label: Interscope
description: DJ Snake is best known for his endless sugar high “Turn Down For What.” His solo album has a few successfully ridiculous tracks but mostly makes you question the need for its existence.

title: Verschiebung
label: Die Orakel
description: The producer Roman Flügel has spread his work across genres and a number of aliases, and on Verschiebung he explores misty, muted techno.

title: Innocence Reaches
label: Polyvinyl
description: After a run of increasingly fussy, exhausting records, Kevin Barnes has started making direct and inviting music again. Innocence Reaches dips its toe into contemporary EDM.

title: Way Down in the Jungle Room
label: Legacy
description: Tracked at Graceland in 1976, the recordings on this double-disc compilation show that Elvis never stopped believing in the power of music, that he never stopped searching for the right song to sing.

title: The Land OST
label: Mass Appeal
description: Nas executive-produced the film and soundtrack The Land, the sort of coming-of-age tale that hip-hop once produced in abundance. The soundtrack features Nas, Erykah Badu, Kanye, Pusha T, and more.

title: Flood Network
label: Joy Void
description: Part of the appeal of Melbourne bedroom-pop artist Katie Dey’s latest is the voyeuristic thrill of hearing knotty music made to satisfy nobody but its author, sometimes at the audience’s exclusion.

title: What Now?
label: Astro Nautico
description: The experimental soul musician's adventurous debut album draws as much from free jazz and IDM as it does funk and R&B, from the Dirty Projectors as much as D'Angelo.

title: Sweatbox Dynasty
label: Ghostly International
description: Thomas Fec (aka Tobacco) has trafficked over the years in the weird, the uncanny, the not-quite-right. His new album tries for a slightly less confrontational, still-unconventional take on synthpop.

title: Well Worn
label: Ghostly International
description: The Australian duo Kllo is consistent in its commitment to moodily lit, immaculately appointed spaces—to stylish understatement at all costs.

title: Generationwhy
label: Columbia
description: Zhu first gained attention with massive 2014 last-call club hit “Faded,” but his debut album is bloated with bland, often downright bad dance music.

title: Suicide Squad: The Album
label: Atlantic
description: Featuring Skrillex, Rick Ross, Grimes, Kehlani, Lil Wayne, and many (many) others, the Suicide Squad OST feels as grim and stapled-together as the movie.

title: Telefone
label: self-released
description: On Telefone, Noname pours the joy and devastation we glimpsed in her various guest spots with artists like Chance the Rapper, Mick Jenkins, and Saba into a rich, somber, and incredibly intimate album.

title: Boy King
label: Domino
description: Wild Beasts' Boy King replaces the ornate detail of its predecessors with machine-tooled funk and pitch-shifted gasps. It's by no means a disaster, but it is a disappointment.

title: Phantoms of Dreamland
label: Music From Memory
description: Each cut on the obscure British-born, Swiss-based musician Michal Turtle's Phantoms of Dreamland presents a strange-yet-charming self-contained little sound world.

title: Cluster Ensemble: Plays Philip Glass
label: Orange Mountain
description: The Cluster Ensemble tackles some of Philip Glass's iconic early works, playing them more crisply and clearly than perhaps any other recording in history.

title: Dangerous
label: Epic
description: At the time of Dangerous, Michael Jackson's universal popularity was on par with pizza and the polio vaccine. It was the last time that Michael Jackson was Michael Jackson.

title: Cam & China
label: self-released
description: Cam & China, twins from Inglewood and veterans of L.A.’s jerkin’ scene, are uniquely attuned to one another,  resulting in some of the year’s fiercest, most viscerally exciting rap music.

title: How It Feels to Be Something On
label: Sub Pop
description: Sunny Day Real Estate admired Fugazi's ethics, but dreamed of being Led Zeppelin and U2, bands that aspired for total transcendence—something they finally achieved on How It Feels to Be Something O**n.

title: Revisions of the Past
label: Bindrune
description: Revisions of the Past reissues two albums by Panopticon, the solo vehicle of Minnesota-via-Kentucky black metal musician Austin Lunn, here remastered by Colin Marston of Krallice, Gorguts, and others.

title: Lovers
label: Blue Note
description: Romantic “mood music” isn’t what most listeners expect from Nels Cline, but on his Blue Note debut, the Wilco guitarist delivers a chamber-orchestra set that visits some American songbook standards.

title: 1-800 DINOSAUR Presents Trim
label: 1-800 DINOSAUR
description: Grime outsider Trim teams up with James Blake and other members of the British electronic music scene for an intriguing, somewhat-cluttered collaborative mixtape.

title: Circle of Light
label: Trunk
description: Delia Derbyshire was an unsung early pioneer in electronic music, and her score for the 1972 film Circle of Light is the longest single piece of recorded music of hers to see release yet.

title: Major Key
label: Epic
description: Major Key is DJ Khaled’s ninth studio album in 10 years, and it’s undoubtedly his best. Depending where you stand on the Khaled spectrum, that may mean nothing or everything.

title: Night Melody
label: Erased Tapes
description: Electronic musician Ryan West's latest release as Rival Consoles has a level of warmth and humanity missing from his earlier records. This is his most expressive and emotional music yet.

title: Impossible Dream
label: Gndwire
description: Haley Bonar’s Impossible Dream is a brisk half-hour of barbed power-pop tunes that sting so sweetly that it’s only after the fact you consider you might need a tetanus shot.

title: The Perfect Luv Tape
label: self-released
description: Lil Uzi Vert's latest mixtape comes at a moment of fever-pitch buzz for the young rapper, reaffirming his talent for synthesizing trends into a catchy melodic soup.

title: Hypercaffium Spazzinate
label: Epitaph
description: *Hypercaffium Spazzinate *is the first LP in over 12 years from the California pop-punk icons, and it relies on the same humor, honesty, and personal experience that has always powered their music.

title: No Beer, No Dad
label: Lauren
description: Portland band Blowout's exuberant debut conveys the sense of being so overwhelmed by frustration, excitement, or any feeling really, that it must be acted on, coordination be damned.

title: Give a Glimpse of What Yer Not
label: Jagjaguwar
description: The latest from the re-reconstituted Dinosaur Jr. proves the equilibrium they discovered on their 2007 comeback Beyond remains intact.

title: Spend the Night With...
label: Sacred Bones
description: Cheena is composed of members from noise and hardcore outfits like Pharmakon and Anasazi, but on their debut, they are a rock band, pure and simple, channeling the New York Dolls.

title: Jaguar Mirror
label: ESP Institute
description: While only four tracks and under 20 minutes of music, the Swedish duo Thunder Tillman’s debut EP spans continents.

title: Hangin’ At the Beach
label: L.A. Club Resource
description: Producer Delroy Edwards combines the faded ‘80s vibe of Ariel Pink and John Maus with a sharp eye toward what moves bodies on dance floors today.

title: For All We Know
label: RCA
description: On For All We Know, Nao autopsies various relationships—with friends, lovers, outgrown versions of herself—and, having decided what went wrong, calmly takes down the perpetrators.

title: The King of Whys
label: Polyvinyl
description: Mike Kinsella expresses ugly sentiments with inverse beauty in Owen's acoustic-heavy return.

title: Shy Layers
label: Growing Bin
description: Shy Layers’ debut is one of the year's great, unexpected pleasures: a deeply engaging, effortlessly listenable collection of Balearic pop with overtones of yacht rock, Kraftwerk, and Graceland.

title: 4OKI
label: Dim Mak
description: Steve Aoki’s latest EP, 4OKI, is a cheap, placebo imitation of a party.

title: Take Down
label: Exit
description: With the debut of his new project Metronome, Mikel Rouse reaches the rarified level of production ambition he first achieved in the ’80s, as he weaved together classical, electronic, and indie rock.

title: S+@dium Rock: Five Nights at the Opera
label: Merge
description: This raucous, epic live album compiles several nights' worth of shows at the Brooklyn venue Shea Stadium, where Titus Andronicus celebrated the release of 2015's The Most Lamentable Tragedy.

title: The Disco’s of Imhotep
label: Technicolour
description: The Disco’s of Imhotep is dance-music outsider Jamal Moss's most approachable collection to date while not diluting his music’s signature oddity.

title: Blood Sugar Sex Magik
label: Warner Bros.
description: On their 1991 breakthrough album, the Red Hot Chili Peppers were the partially-clothed id, barreling toward the funk and stumbling across inclusiveness along the way.

title: Stranger to Violence
label: Profound Lore
description: The Queens, New York-based outfit Psalm Zero explore the fertile territory between metal and new wave on their sophomore album.

title: Drool Sucker
label: Topshelf
description: The unpredictable Drool Sucker kicks off a series of EPs from the transcontinental band No Joy in which they attempt to shake off the “shoegaze revival” tag once and for all.

title: Sky Girl
label: Efficient Space
description: Two French DJs evoke heartbreak and desolation in a compilation of little-heard gems.

title: Let Me Hang You
label: Ernest Jenning
description: Let Me Hang You is the result of long-shelved sessions from the 1990s, during which Burroughs recited some favorite riffs from Naked Lunch. The album conjures only a portion of the book’s wild power.

title: Boleros Valses y Mas
label: Stones Throw
description: The Los Angeles producer's first Stones Throw release takes the bolero, the valse, and other traditional Latin forms and plays them on a solitary Oberheim synthesizer.

title: A Mulher do Fim do Mundo (The Woman at the End of the World)
label: Mais Um Discos
description: 79-year-old samba icon and Brazilian national hero Elza Soares offers a searing, surging fusion that combines Afro-Brazilian styles with wiry, dissonant strands of punk and noise-rock.

title: D.T.S.N.T.
label: Ultra
description: The quietly virtuosic Parisian producer STWO worked on Drake’s “Weston Road Flows” from VIEWS, and his debut EP is chock-full of impressive guest vocalists, testifying to his ear for talent.

title: Lil Durk 2X
label: Def Jam
description: After a forgettable Def Jam debut, 2x realizes Durk’s full potential as drill’s last major-label hope.

title: Late Nights: Europe
label: self-released
description: Reportedly recorded in 2 weeks, Late Nights: Europe is a polished, 14-track libertine manifesto, wrapping up a trilogy of odes to the grown and sexy. Featuring Ty Dolla $ign, Wiz Khalifa, and more.

title: The Bird & the Rifle
label: CN Records
description: On her Dave Cobb-produced latest, country singer/songwriter Lori McKenna shows her remarkable facility for conveying the inner lives of women trapped in soured relationships.

title: Noise Patterns
label: Physical Editions
description: Composer, designer and programmer Tristan Perich uses very small objects—microchips—to pose very big questions about art, music, and the state of the “album.”

title: Dead Revolution
label: Metal Blade
description: John Cobbett is one of modern metal’s premier guitarists. In Hammers of Misfortune, he reinvigorates ’70s progressive rock and the hard rock of Deep Purple, Rainbow, and Uli Jon Roth-era Scorpions.

title: Guidance
label: Sargent House
description: There's an organic and unforced feel to the latest album by Chicago-based post-rock trio Russian Circles, as if songs were allowed to grow wild rather than carefully cultivated.

title: Summer Songs 2
label: Quality Control
description: On his latest mixtape, the divisive Atlanta rapper sounds best when chasing fresher, weirder, spacier styles instead of trying to live up to hip-hop’s storied traditions.

title: Unfinished
label: Technicolour
description: On his sixth release, lo-fi techno producer Florian Kupfer creates music as airy and pleasantly rudimentary as a papier-mâché sculpture.

title: Everybody Looking
label: Atlantic
description: Emerging from prison clean and sober in May, Gucci Mane releases an album looking to capitalize on his massive influence. Featuring Kanye West, Young Thug, and Drake.

title: Command Your Weather
label: Joyful Noise
description: The duo Big Business’ latest is an anxious and adventurous little record, too eccentric and playful to be accepted as metal but too loaded and loud to be taken as most anything else.

title: Young Jefe 2
label: 300 Entertainment
description: On the sequel to his breakout 2014 mixtape, the Washington, D.C. rapper Shy Glizzy is simply a joy to listen to, one of the most distinctive and technically adventurous rappers working today.

title: This Is Gap Dream
label: Burger
description: Gap Dream's morose new record documents a music nerd's midlife meltdown, over junk-littered garage rock, rudimentary synth-pop, and no-budget prog flourishes.

title: Titans in the Flesh
label: Coalmine
description: With their second collaborative project, this rapper/producer duo offer a well-studied paean to hip-hop’s past. You could call it a boom baptism.

title: Love & Hate
label: Polydor
description: Singer Michael Kiwanuka’s new album* *is a sprawling soul opus full of longing and self-assessment.  It's a bittersweet offering, growing more melancholy as it plays.

title: Coolaid
label: Entertainment One
description: On Snoop Dogg’s 14th studio album Coolaid, he returns to hip-hop as both a resident and a tourist.

title: Cistern
label: The Leaf Label
description: Composer and songwriter Jherek Bischoff's third record is an oceanic song cycle that encourages listeners to drop down into their own mind, a safe space in the dark where they are comfortably alone.

title: Call by Night
label: Sacred Bones
description: Fresh & Onlys guitarist Wymond Miles cultivates an arch air of high drama in his solo LPs. The songs on Call By Night touch on the exhilaration that sometimes accompanies sadness and uncertainty.

title: Ambulance
label: Partisan
description: On their gloomy new record, the psych-rockers the Amazing grab hold of a small range of emotions—depression, regret, angst, longing—and hang on for dear life.

title: Savage Mode
label: Slaughter Gang
description: On Savage Mode, the dry-voiced and deadpan trap rapper 21 Savage recounts a life that has known nothing but violence. It's his strongest release, thanks to sleek production by Metro Boomin.

title: Kuiper
label: Luaka Bop
description: On his new EP, producer Floating Points (nee Sam Shepherd) offers two extended tracks that occasionally sound like Neu! with steroids and 40 years of additional recording technology on their side.

title: Drankin’ & Drivin’
label: Deep Entertainment
description: Houston rap icon Z-Ro's gorgeous, languid baritone frequently lapses into singing. His latest album paints with just a few colors, but he continually finds new ways to blend them.

title: Four Meditations / Sound Geometries
label: Sub Rosa
description: The legendary 84-year old composer, accordionist, and electronic pioneer reaffirms her mastery at conjuring three-dimensional worlds from simple words on a page.

title: Gqom Oh! x Crudo Volta Mixtape
label: Gqom Oh!
description: This collaborative mixtape between Gqom Oh! and the Rome-based Crudo Volta collective showcases some of the best music that gqom—a raw, brash dance music coming from Durban—has ever produced.

title: No Hard Feelings
label: Interscope
description: Chicago rapper Dreezy is a drill-adjacent upstart from the South Side, and her major-label debut is a fully-formed offering that seamlessly balances rugged raps with pristine pop songs.

title: Mono No Aware
label: Alcopop!
description: The British punk band Johnny Foreigner’s songs often seem made up of components of older emo and pop-punk songs, but remembered wrong, reversed and compressed into anxious nodes.

title: Horror Zone
label: Nu-Roots
description: Though 40 years have passed between albums, roots reggae legend Max Romeo's latest picks up right where the classic Lee “Scratch” Perry-produced War Ina Babylon left off.

title: HEAVN
label: Closed Sessions
description: With the assistance of fellow Chicagoans Chance the Rapper, Saba, and Kweku Collins, R&B artist Jamila Woods makes vital, resonant protest music that sounds like a children’s playground.

title: Community Service 2!
label: Unknown
description: Chance the Rapper compatriot Towkio sometimes raps great, vivid tales about his life in Chicago. Sometime’s he’s funny and weird. And sometimes he falls victim to cruddy trap beats and generic lyrics.

title: Indifferent Rivers Romance End
label: The Flenser
description: The California duo Wreck and Reference strip away the basics of metal, redefining the genre even as they sit outside it. On their new album, their songcraft catches up to their uncompromising gloom.

title: Centres
description: Ian William Craig's Centres is a swirling and alchemical blend of drone, keyboards, and manipulated vocals. The more time you spend with it, the further you will want to get lost in it.

title: PRINCESS
label: True Panther
description: The Atlanta singer/producer Abra makes vintage, '80s-sounding R&B with the production values and aesthetic of bedroom pop.

title: Operator
label: Last Gang
description: More than any other MSTRKRFT release, *Operator *sounds like the work of a band — one with punk DNA coursing through its army of analog synths.

label: Fragile
description: The Berlin- and London-based photographer Wolfgang Tillmans has long had ties to music and club culture, and now he has released a musing and quizzical techno release of his own.

title: IV
label: Innovative Leisure
description: On their fourth record, the succinctly titled *IV, *BADBADNOTGOOD rein in their jam-band impulses, delivering a velvet-crushed portrait of an effervescent lounge act in the 21st century.

title: 32 Levels
label: Columbia
description: The influential hip-hop producer's debut album, 32 Levels, has two distinct sides: a uniformly strong rap side and a pop side that’s not nearly as engaging or distinctive.

title: Elysia Crampton Presents: Demon City
label: Break World
description: Demon City, Virginia producer Elysia Crampton's follow-up to her sumptuous debut American Drift, is a wonder of concision and represents another massive leap forward in her growth.

title: Camp Cope
label: Poison City
description: This Melbourne trio's effusive, empathic, and emphatic indie-rock debut examines shame the way 69 Love Songs x-rays love.

title: Devotional Songs
label: Honest Jon's
description: Shackleton, who has made himself a genre of one with his dark, dramatic dub-inspired work, takes a turn toward the operatic.

title: Caramel
label: Planet Mu
description: Konx-om-Pax is the project of electronic musician Tom Scholefield. His second LP Caramel fondly invokes nostalgia for the rave era, playing like the faded tracers and seared after-images that remain.

title: Tusk
label: Warner Bros.
description: Fleetwood Mac's beautiful and terrifically strange 1979 LP Tusk poses the question: What happens when love dissipates, and you have to find a new thing to believe in? What if that thing is work?

title: Eleven into Fifteen: a 130701 Compilation
description: Eleven Into Fifteen: a 130701 Compilation is a new anthology pulling unreleased work from 130701’s roster, celebrating not just the label but the hazily-defined genre of “post-classical.”

title: Hit Reset
label: Hardly Art
description: The Julie Ruin’s second album, Hit Reset, is bandleader and punk icon Kathleen Hanna's most commanding release since her manifesto-writing days.

title: Sketches from an Island 2
label: International Feel
description: The British-born producer Mark Barrott played a big role in establishing the Balearic sound. Sketches from an Island 2 is the rare sequel that improves on the original.

title: New Introductory Lectures on the System of Transcendental Qabala
label: YLYLCYN
description: Liturgy frontman Hunter Hunt-Hendrix's latest work is electronic side project Kel Valhaal, which mixes his interests in Southern rap with ambient drones and glitch.

title: Nothing’s Real
label: Polydor
description: On her latest record, Shura is at the vanguard of a scene of young queer pop stars who are updating the ’80s model of self-sufficient, fully liberated mainstream pop.

title: DJ-Kicks
label: !K7
description: Glaswegian DJ Jackmaster is best known for his ability to traverse genres, decades and moods in a few sweaty hours, and the prestigious DJ-Kicks series is an ideal format for his talents.

title: Stateless
label: Temporary Residence
description: Tangents artfully mix acoustic instruments and electronics in pieces that combine improvisation with careful processing. At their best, they bring to mind Can, Tortoise, Four Tet, and the Necks.

title: Double Bind
label: Spunk
description: On their latest album, New Zealand's Trust Punks leave behind jangly pop for a plunge into acidic post-punk, while their lyrics cast a jaundiced eye at a crumbling society.

title: Made To Measure
label: Warp
description: The London-based electronic duo's latest record was written well before Brexit, but its austere, dystopian murk reflects the deflated, anxious, uncertain national mood of their home.

title: Blank Face LP
label: Interscope
description: Blank Face LP is a collection of catchy, urgent gangsta rap songs that show the South Central native at his charismatic best, gallows humor and tough talk failing to obscure a humane core.

title: Plum
label: Brunette Editions
description: John Roberts' pristine and absorbing third LP finds the avant-garde techno producer speaking the language of dance music without actually making much music to dance to.

title: Windings
label: Feedelity
description: Unfussy, bursting with confidence, and freshly energized, the 3 songs on Hans-Peter Lindstrøm's new EP return to the space-disco euphoria of his most-loved work.

title: Blisters in the Pit of My Heart
label: Dirtnap
description: Martha’s sophomore LP offers fodder for critical thought that can be digested while pogoing.

title: Gone is Gone
label: Rise
description: Gone is Gone is a power trio made of key members from Mastodon, Queens of the Stone Age, and the recently reactivated At the Drive-In.

title: blackSUMMERS’night
label: Columbia
description: The cool, shimmering* blackSUMMERS’night *is probably Maxwell’s most cohesive effort since Embrya, fit to soundtrack sessions of sex so exquisite and transcendental, tantric comes off as boring.

title: Church EP
label: True Panther
description: Kelsey Lu recorded her debut EP live in a Brooklyn church with a loop pedal and Chairlift’s Patrick Wimberly co-producing. The music lingers and haunts, rich with sadness and unease.

title: Black Bubblegum
label: DFA
description: The Black Dice member's latest solo outing is ramshackle, blithe, and relatively accessible, with cleaner vocals than usual and a sense of demented whimsy.

title: Take Her Up To Monto
label: Play It Again Sam
description: The underrated Irish post-disco singer returns with her second album in two years after a lengthy dry spell. The songs flit amongst genres, united only by her fearless, restless spirit.

title: Resolutionary (Songs 1979-1982)
label: Staubgold
description: Resolutionary (Songs 1979-1982) reintroduces us to the indomitable Vivien Goldman—music journalist, reggae scholar, NYU’s “Professor of Punk”—whose recordings helped build post-punk at its magic hour.

title: Dream World
label: AraabMuzik Label Group
description: AraabMuzik’s long-awaited sophomore LP Dream World is packed with more sonic diversity than his beloved debut, Electronic Dream. This works both for and against him.

title: GØGGS
label: In the Red
description: Ty Segall's latest collaboration—with Ex-Cult's Chris Shaw and Fuzz's Charles Moothart—isn't a revolution. They’re just three friends, hellbent on sustaining guitar music’s urgency and simplicity

title: The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill
label: Columbia
description: The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill is a declaration of independence. With it, Ms. Hill put the entire genre of hip-hop on blast and elevated heartbreak to spiritual proportions.

title: Into the Light
label: Chaos Kitchen
description: Guitarist Marisa Anderson's latest album soundtracks a theoretical sci-fi Western of her own invention, where it’s up to the listener to fill in the cinematic details.

title: Summer 08
label: Because Music
description: Metronomy's latest record strips away any pretense that they are a band, focusing on its sole creator, Joe Mount. The album solidifies his own idiosyncratic brand of standoffish funk.

title: Fallen
label: Apron
description: Steven Julien specializes in a jubilantly no-frills strain of house and techno, and his debut album is bare-bones—just gnarled acid sequences, bare-knuckle drum programming, and drifting synths.

title: Live at Third Man Records
label: Third Man
description: Live at Third Man Records* *is the first live album by comedy duo Scharpling & Wurster. It's a concise set that seems focused on celebrating their act, rather than expanding on it.

title: Magma
label: Roadrunner
description: The acclaimed avant-metal outfit Gojira’s sixth full-length LP is their most accessible release yet, melodically immediate and charged with emotion.

title: Wildflower
label: Modular
description: The Avalanches return with their first new album in 16 years.

title: Nite-Funk
label: Glydezone
description: Nite Jewel and Dâm-Funk have been teasing a collaboration for years, and their long-awaited EP, they capture lightning in a bottle. More, please.

title: Streets of Compton
label: Entertainment One
description: The soundtrack to the The Game's three-part documentary series Streets of Compton feels like a missed opportunity for the rapper to embrace his comfort zone.

title: Cheetah
label: Warp
description: The newest Aphex Twin since Richard D. James returned from his extended hiatus shows a simpler side of his music, with slower tempos and spine-tinglingly rich tunes and timbres.

title: Hot Hot Heat
label: Culvert Music
description: After 17 years, five albums, and numerous line up changes, Hot Hot Heat are calling it quits with their final, self-titled LP, which looks back on things with surface cheeriness and tangible fatigue.

title: Paradise Gallows
label: Relapse
description: Paradise Gallows finds the Richmond, Virginia five-piece alternatively aiming to be both the world’s heaviest act and also the prettiest.

title: Weaves
label: Buzz
description: The Toronto indie rock quartet Weaves' self-titled debut is an impressive album about incapacitating infatuation.

title: California
label: Viking Wizard Eyes
description: Blink-182's seventh album wants to be a pop-punk eminence album, evidence humbly submitted that this aging pack of skater brats is still young, selectively dumb, and full of commiserating angst.

title: Primary Colours
label: RCA
description: After scoring a #1 hit with 2014's "Rude,"  the Canadian Rastatryhardians return with an album that posits them as "Magic! The Career Artists."

title: Delirium Tremens
label: Mute
description: Former Bad Seeds sideman Mick Harvey revisits the songbook of Serge Gainbourg for the third time, moving past the salacious icon’s signature songs into his oddities.

title: Alice Bag
label: Don Giovanni
description: Alice Bag was the lead singer and co-founder of the Bags, one of the first punk rock bands to emerge from L.A., and Alice Bag is her first solo record in a 40-year career.

title: Anagrams
label: Melodic
description: Stephen Steinbrink has been bouncing around the West Coast indie underground for over a decade now.  The singer/songwriter's new album is his best, with winsome shades of Elliott Smith's XO.

title: The Bride
label: Parlophone
description: Natasha Khan's latest album as Bat For Lashes is a richly theatrical concept album detailing the story of a woman left at the altar after the husband dies in a car crash on the way to the wedding.

title: Different Class
label: Island
description: On 1995's Different Class, Pulp and Jarvis Cocker were arty outsiders worming their way into the lives of ordinary folk, and they became pop in its most democratically widespread sense.

title: Nice As Fuck
label: Love’s Way
description: The post-punk project Nice As Fuck is the most low-stakes album Jenny Lewis has ever been a part of, but it hits its mark.

title: New English
label: G.O.O.D. Music
description: 19-year-old Brooklyn rapper Desiigner emerged from nowhere to collaborate with Kanye on The Life of Pablo. On New English, he sounds like the last five years of hip-hop watered down.

title: Uniola
label: Tiny Engines
description: Look Mexico's Uniola is a caffeinated kind of indie rock that works to the rhythm of daily life, while their lyrics treat soul-searching as natural, inescapable part of living.

title: Human Story 3
label: Break World
description: James Ferraro’s latest album feels a bit like a didactic student art project; it finds the vaporwave pioneer doubling down on the themes of 2011’s Far Side Virtual with a much heavier hand.

title: Autodrama
label: Manifesto
description: The L.A. band Puro Instinct evaporates some of the shoegaze fog around their debut for some tentative bigger pop maneuvers.

title: Entities Inertias Faint Beings
label: Room40
description: Composer/performer/improviser David Toop’s latest release traces the seam between sound and music, paying attention to the hidden sounds that surround us and turning silence inside out.

title: Freetown Sound
label: Domino
description: Dev Hynes' third album as Blood Orange is a searing and soothing personal document, striking the same resonant chords as Kendrick Lamar’s *To Pimp a Butterfly or *D’Angelo’s Black Messiah.

title: I, Gemini
label: Transgressive
description: The teenaged duo Let's Eat Grandma explore the nightmarish whimsy of nursery rhymes and folktales with a distinctly English flavor on their chilling and impressive debut.

title: Sound in Time
label: Dischord
description: With warped lyrics and a thing for repetition, Lungfish embodied the D.C. area’s post-hardcore innovations. No one else has gotten as weird since.

title: Indigo
label: River Tiber
description: On his debut LP, the Toronto producer and singer/songwriter Tommy Paxton-Beesley, aka River Tiber, sums up the chilly, forlorn pop sound that has defined his city.

title: The Magic
label: Polyvinyl
description: The avant-pop stalwarts return with one of their loosest and most rock-heavy records yet, slightly bending their own rules while remaining stubbornly singular.

title: Going By
label: Double Double Whammy
description: Felix Walworth's second album of indie-pop under the name Told Slant addresses questions of trauma, confusion, and loss with frankness and intimacy.

title: Fire
label: Don Giovanni
description: Amy Klein’s solo debut, after stints as the grinning rhythm guitarist in Titus Andronicus and several other projects, feels like the demo that your college roommate’s band just made.

title: b
label: Trip
description: Bjarki is a closely watched new techno producer from Iceland with a deft touch for big, dumb ragers. On the first of 3 new releases this year, he treats old-school techno with classic-rock reverence.

title: Codex Obscura Nomina
label: Debemur Morti
description: This split LP from Blut Aus Nord and Ævangelist explores black metal’s capacity to accommodate an array of sounds and moods, not just grimness.

title: Otero War
label: Cinematic
description: Like the two Caveman albums before it, Otero War could be an accessory to a generic and fictionalized network-tv retelling of “indie rock in the 2010s.”

title: True Sadness
label: Republic
description: It’s fitting that the Avett Brothers’ most disappointing record yet bears the title of True Sadness. Is this some kind of play for the Top 40, or just instrumental bloat and trite sentiment?

title: Jay II
label: Mint
description: Musician/producer Jay Arner excels at sneaking despondence and alienation into airtight, earwormy pop gems. On Jay II he explores his love of New Wave and other '80s pop.

title: Yoncalla
label: Cascine
description: Yumi Zouma’s first album closes a longtime distance between its members and delivers bright, complex disco-rock.

title: Muzik
label: PHLEX
description: Several years removed from their turn-of-the-decade peak, Delorean's frothy dance-pop has soured somewhat.

title: The Mountain Will Fall
label: Mass Appeal
description: DJ Shadow trades in his turntables and MPC for a copy of Ableton and embarks upon a freewheeling, low-stakes journey through the contemporary sounds that inspire his practice.

title: Warm Leatherette
label: Island
description: Warm Leatherette, Grace Jones’ career-shifting 1980 release, gives a glimpse of the artist just as her true genius was coming into sharp focus.

title: American Tunes
label: Nonesuch
description: American Tunes is a posthumous album from the legendary musician, songwriter, and New Orleans legend Allen Toussaint, whose smartly funky touch enlivens a selection of standards.

title: The Dreaming Room
label: Sony
description: Laura Mvula is a classically trained vocalist with an orchestral pop style all her own. Her second album is filled with her rich and moving voice and is laden with sonic surprises.

title: Post Plague
label: Telephone Explosion
description: Toronto trio Odonis Odonis forgo their rowdy surf/garage mix for a pulsating, John Carpenter-esque goth palette, while their lyrics explore the dire consequences of unchecked technological progress.

title: Libras
label: Joyful Noise
description: Matthew Friedberger's latest is an instrumental effort with Sebadoh (and sometimes Fiery Furnaces) drummer Bob D’Amico. The best moments have Friedberger's antic playfulness and melodic gift.

title: Moog for Love
label: Island
description: After last year's underwhelming Caracal, the Disclosure brothers' surprise-dropped EP shows that thrill isn’t quite gone, but it’s definitely not the same.

title: Tween
label: Merge
description: Tween is a collection of outtakes from the perennially overlooked Baltimore indie rock band's previous two LPs, yet it manages to capture the full scope of their vision.

title: Secretly Susan
label: Twosyllable
description: Melbourne artist Sui Zhen's world is brilliant and uncanny, and her music explores a familiar theme—the thinness of digital-media life—with a fresh eye.

title: Blood // Sugar // Secs // Traffic
label: Sub Pop
description: The Pittsburgh quartet the Gotobeds trade in the dour, verbose post-punk of bands like Parquet Courts and Protomartyr, with lyrics that suggest they're aware they walk a well-traveled road.

title: Puberty 2
label: Dead Oceans
description: On her fourth album, Mitski makes a resounding personal statement and stakes out her territory as one of the most compelling voices in the sphere of indie rock.

title: Magic 19
label: self-released
description: Bishop Nehru debuted as DOOM's protege and signed and split with Nas' label all before age 19. Now, he stakes out his own territory on a mostly self-produced effort that blasts off for other galaxies.

title: Delayer
label: Magic Bullet
description: RLYR features Pelican guitarist Trevor Shelley de Brauw, Locrian percussionist Steve Hess, and Russian Circles bassist Colin DeKuiper. Their debut is forty minutes of uncommonly optimistic post-rock.

title: Brigid Mae Power
label: Tompkins Square
description: Irish folk singer Brigid Mae Power's latest occupies a liminal space made up of droning guitars, metallic piano reverberations, and lyrics that trace some barely escaped threat.

title: Still Brazy
label: Def Jam
description: Compton rapper YG's follow up to 2014's My Krazy Life parts with DJ Mustard's snaps and dips into rich, classic g-funk, while YG grapples with the contradictions of being a celebrity gangster.

title: The Big Cover-Up
label: Olsen
description: The Norwegian producer's latest EP remixes a handful of strange tunes, from Vangelis to Boney M.  to Yellow Magic Orchestra, that have entered the disco canon.

title: ELDORADO
label: RCA
description: On his debut album, Ro James delivers a pleasant but only sporadically exciting R&B affair.

title: The Glowing Man
label: Young God
description: Swans close their current chapter on a subdued but powerful note.

title: PAGAN
label: Mixpak
description: South London musician Benjy Keating is signed to the acclaimed independent dancehall label Mixpak, where he makes a strange and subdued DIY bedroom-pop version of dancehall.

title: Media in the Service of Terror
label: Hospital Productions
description: In his industrial techno guise Vatican Shadow, Dominick Fernow (aka Prurient) explores some of his most simultaneously bleak and clubby music yet.

title: The Getaway
label: Warner Bros.
description: The Red Hot Chili Peppers' eleventh album is their first since 1989’s Mothers’ Milk without Rick Rubin behind the boards, opting instead for Danger Mouse and Nigel Godrich.

title: Friday Night
label: Merge
description: On his sometimes-hilarious, seat-of-the-pants live concert album, Arcade Fire's Will Butler shows the good and bad sides of winging it and hoping your audience follows.

title: Weval
label: Kompakt
description: With their self-titled debut, Weval have made the rare electronic record that is so strong and obviously appealing that it can't help but end up in the hands of casual listeners.

title: All Things Must Pass
label: Apple
description: Given his own studio, his own canvas, and his own space, George Harrison did what no other solo Beatle did on All Things Must Pass: He changed the terms of what an album could be.

title: A Youthful Dream
label: Fat Possum
description: Aarhus punks Yung take the austere vibe of their big-brother bands like Iceage and shoot it through with some old-fashioned American-fuck-up energy, a la Paul Westerberg and Jay Reatard.

title: You Will Never Be One of Us
label: Nuclear Blast
description: Nails make music for when you look at life and see little of value, for when you're feeling bitter and alone. On their latest, they make a little room for others to stare at the void with them.

title: case/lang/veirs
label: Anti-
description: The debut from k.d. lang, Neko Case, and Laura Veirs isn’t a springboard or a resting place for any of these vets. It's an exquisite tribute to connection and reflection on the things that bind us.

title: Alpha
label: !K7
description: Audion is the minimal-techno guise of Matthew Dear, and often a vent for his most antic impulses. Alpha jettisons the wilder stuff for a sleek, toned-down, crisper affair.

title: On My One
label: Island
description: The pop-star-baiting, credibility-seeking, Noel-Gallagher-approved (and then shunned), surly major label rocker Jake Bugg turns in one of the most baffling collections of music in recent memory.

title: EARTH
label: Reprise
description: Neil Young’s not-exactly-live album EARTH, a set of songs from across his career about food awareness, feels like the first time in a while that Young has been in on his own joke.

title: Last Year Was Complicated
label: Island
description: On Last Year Was Complicated, Nick Jonas follows in the tried-and-true “I'm having sex now, guys” footsteps of boybanders past.

title: Professional Sunflow
label: Superior Viaduct
description: Just as they did with dub icons The Congos, Sun Araw collaborate with New Age icon Laraaji on the hazy, welcoming* Professional Sunflow. *

title: Liquid Cool
label: Gloriette
description: After a pop-oriented push on 2012’s One Second of Love, Nite Jewel's Ramona Gonzalez reclaims the murky, DIY vision of her Altered Zones-era releases.

title: Early Recordings
label: Merge
description: Katie Crutchfield's first EP as Waxahatchee, originally released on cassette, unfolds like a pleasant secret on the brink of being passed around.

title: Midnight
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Dan Lissvik's latest solo album echoes his past glory with the Swedish dance-rockers Studio, but teases when it could fulfill.

title: Mandatory Check
label: EMPIRE
description: This Sacramento rapper has had a busy couple of years, and though his latest often sounds rushed, he remains one of the foremost narrative stylists in hip-hop.

title: Turn to Gold
label: Infinity Cat
description: On Diarrhea Planet's third album, arena-rock ambition clashes with D.I.Y. scuzz–and a vocalist coup may be in order.

title: Thick as Thieves
label: Glassnote
description: On their third full-length, the Temper Trap capture some of the crowd-pleasing sound of their debut, unleashing likable enough pop-rock with a bright electronic sheen.

title: Jackie Lynn
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Haley Fohr's newest songwriting persona doesn't mince words–but she also leaves her full potential unknown.

title: Argonautica
label: Firehouse 12
description: The experimental trumpeter Nate Wooley is known for disassembling his instrument and making music from its various parts. Here, he pays homage to one of his mentors with epic, rock-infused tumult.

title: Why Are You OK
label: Interscope
description: Working with producer Jason Lytle, formerly of the band Grandaddy, Ben Bridwell has crafted his best album in nearly a decade, but problems still remain.

title: What One Becomes
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Sumac, Aaron Turner's post-Isis trio, succeed at making minimalist doom metal because they recall what fans of Isis loved without resembling Turner's past work in the slightest.

title: For Those Of You Who Have Never (And Also Those Who Have)
label: Proibito
description: Kansas City producer Huerco S.'s second album is ambient music through and through—though it’s informed by a memory of club music, which hangs over it like a ringing in the ears.

title: Movie!
label: Gronland
description: Holger Czukay left Can in 1978 and began a solo career shortly afterward. His debut solo album, now reissued, reveals an impish, cut-and-paste jester behind Can’s impassive façade.

title: The Digging Remedy
label: Warp
description: Warp Records mainstays Plaid have staked out a well-defined territory over two decades: They make highly listenable melodic IDM, warm and playful. Their latest album doesn't rip up the blueprint.

title: Hounds of Love
label: EMI
description: With her self-produced fifth album, Kate Bush became a total auteur, embracing the possibilities of digital sampling synthesizers and creating a perfect marriage of technique and exploration.

title: Fall Forever
label: Kanine
description: On their bleak new album, the Brighton band abandons all hints of jangle-pop and dives into extraterrestrial synths, ominously bowed bass, and guitars distorted beyond recognition.

title: Wild Things
label: Polyvinyl
description: After 2012's spiky, lonely, underrated Anxiety, Ladyhawke returns to '80s-inflected synth-pop on Wild Things.

title: Fantasma
label: Lefse
description: Cornelius's Fantasma was a high point of the mid-'90s Shibuya-kei scene, an eclectic crate-diggers' subgenre that celebrated old sounds. Its vinyl reissue shows it still sounds fresh in 2016.

title: Piano
label: Moshi Moshi
description: The Hot Chip frontman's third solo record is his most straightforward and surprisingly personal effort, a collection of songs for just piano and voice.

title: Strange Little Birds
label: STUNVOLUME
description: With their post-return jitters under control, Garbage have solidified that return with Strange Little Birds, their darkest, most intimate LP and the band’s strongest effort in 15 years.

title: Emotions and Math
label: ATO
description: Singer/songwriter Margaret Glaspy's Emotions and Math is a collection of compact grunge-rock and breezy torch songs that variously recall Elliott Smith and Joni Mitchell.

title: Victorious
label: M-Plant
description: Detroit techno legend Robert Hood, under his Floorplan alias, invites his teenage daughter Lyric to coproduce Victorious, which is more open, more anthemic, and brighter than much of his past work.

title: Foiled Again
label: Carpark
description: Speedy Ortiz's latest EP features two unreleased tracks from Foil Deer as well as two remixes of “Puffer,” one featuring a verse from rapper Lizzo and one by Open Mike Eagle.

title: There’s Alot Going On
label: Roc Nation
description: On his new EP, Vic Mensa opens up like never before, airing his mistakes and fears.

title: Stranger to Stranger
label: Concord
description: Stranger to Stranger is arguably the best album of Paul Simon's uneven post-Graceland solo career. His reliably melodic songwriting is buoyed by his most adventurous arrangements in years.

title: Breakin’ Point
label: Ingrid
description: Breakin’ Point, PB&J's sixth album, enlists big-name producers like Paul Epworth, Greg Kurstin, and Emile Haynie. The result is the big pop album they've always seemed on the verge of making.

title: Black Terry Cat
label: Anti-
description: On her second album, Xenia Rubinos negotiates a world that has prescribed ideas about how she should be—particularly as a person of color—and incisively questions her place outside of those roles.

title: Ha, Ha, He.
label: Captured Tracks
description: With its two-tone album cover, terse songwriting, and Albini-style, hands-off recording, *Ha, Ha, He. is Mourn's *period piece, conjuring the grave austerity of mid-'90s post-punk.

title: Love You to Death
label: Warner Bros.
description: After going synth-pop on 2013's Heartthrob, Tegan and Sara team up once again with super-producer Greg Kurstin for the follow up. At their best, they boil love songs down to their aching essence.

title: Ash & Ice
label: Domino
description: Ash & Ice is The Kills’ first album in five years and they encompass everything they’ve done before, as well as bringing in boombox beats with Brazilian and Afro-pop influences.

title: Future Present Past EP
label: Cult
description: On their newest EP, The Strokes continue to perform “The Strokes” for a new generation of younger and casual listeners.

title: It Came From N.Y.C.
label: Numero Group
description: They may have found fame through Beavis and Butt-Head, but in their early days, White Zombie operated in the same NYC underground as Swans and Sonic Youth. This Numero Group box set tells the story.

title: Levitate
label: R&S
description: At its best, this short, punchy album feels like a distillation of everything that has made British producer Lone's work great so far.

title: Masterpiece
label: Saddle Creek
description: On the rangy folk-rock band Big Thief's Saddle Creek debut Masterpiece, the songs sound cherry-picked over a lifetime of writing, the stories carefully compiled.

title: Big Bossin Vol. 1
label: self-released
description: On Big Bossin Vol. 1, Detroit underground hero and Texas-based producer Cardo Got Wings work together to make a smooth, technicolor tribute to classic LA gangster rap.

title: My Best Human Face
label: Jagjaguwar
description: After two records of quiet, lonely, piano-only music, Spencer Krug returns to the guitars, bleeping synths, and pounding rhythms of his best-loved work.

title: Basses Loaded
label: Ipecac
description: Perhaps for the first time ever, the Melvins sound unfocused and—worse—like their music is beginning to lack energy.

title: Light Upon the Lake
label: Secretly Canadian
description: On their winsome debut, the duo Whitney make a warm, simple and profoundly enjoyable rock'n'roll record, evoking the earnestness and innocence of Girls.

title: Still They Pray
label: Relapse
description: The new album from Cough could have arrived anytime during, say, the last three decades and placed the Richmond doom metal quartet alongside the ranks of Candlemass or Cathedral, Sleep or Saint Vitus.

title: Eyes on the Lines
label: Matador
description: Folk-rocker Steve Gunn's latest album is a rich and amiable meditation about travel and transition, about exploring, wandering, and letting yourself get lost.

title: The Wailing Wailers
label: Yep Roc
description: Not only does The Wailing Wailers highlight the first major recordings of Bob Marley, but the happy, bouncy, optimistic sound is also the sound of post-independence Jamaica.

label: Epic
description: On their new album, Fifth Harmony are at their best when grappling with the age-old girl-group concern of how to reconcile independence with love.

title: Collapse
label: Leaving
description: *Collapse *is a strange and beautiful record that refuses categorization, traipsing through the fields of house, free jazz and musique concrète on the way to something inscrutably Other.

title: DJ-Kicks
label: !K7
description: West Coast groove aficionado Dâm-Funk offers an engrossing selection of tracks that are as dreamy as they are funky in his installment of the DJ-Kicks mix series.

title: iiiDrops
label: self-released
description: Joey Purp is a member of Chance the Rapper’s Savemoney Crew, and iiiDrops is his most well-rounded and definitive effort: He comes off as boastful and thoughtful, socially aware and defiantly filthy.

title: Skin
label: Transgressive
description: The young Australian DJ/Producer's profile has grown immensely in the past few years. On his new album, he recruits an all-star cast including Beck, Little Dragon, Vince Staples, and more.

title: Awkward Pop Songs
label: Creep
description: At their best, the Philly punk band JANK highlights the connection between emo’s fourth wave and the unconventional, genre-spanning pop of the Dismemberment Plan or the Unicorns.

title: Modern Country
label: Merge
description: Guitarist William Tyler returns backed by an all-star band that notably includes Wilco’s Glenn Kotche and Megafaun’s Phil Cook, summoning a wide range of moods and telling stories without vocals.

title: Suck on This
label: ZEF
description: Suck on This is a teaser for an upcoming full-length from the South African rap trio, but more often than not these days, Die Antwoord comes off as tired and trying way too hard.

title: Folding Time
label: Hotflush
description: Nearly five years after their debut marked the peak convergence of late-2000s bass music and its myriad influences—dubstep, R&B, footwork, house, ambient, hardcore—Sepalcure return with a second album.

title: Congrats
label: Innovative Leisure
description: The instrumental act's latest album finds them revisiting their circa-05 roots, offering tracks that are as pummeling as they are danceable.

title: Angry Angles
label: Goner
description: Angry Angles captured legendary Memphis garage-rock wildman Jay Reatard in between projects and on the brink of his solo career.

title: Mark Kozelek Sings Favorites
label: Caldo Verde
description: On Mark Kozelek Sings Favorites, the Sun Kil Moon singer offers piano-and-voice interpretations of songs ranging from Modest Mouse's “Float On” to “Send in the Clowns.”

title: Rock the Fuck on Forever
label: Pop Wig
description: Baltimore melodic hardcore band Angel Du$t describe themselves as a mix of the Bad Brains and the Lemonheads, and their latest mixes mash notes with double-time tempos.

title: Mosey
label: New West
description: Ontario musician Daniel Romano's fifth solo full-length finds him relying on classic country flourishes to build simple songs that look to the great beyond.

title: Minor Victories
label: Fat Possum
description: Minor Victories includes members of Mogwai, Editors, and Slowdive, and their self-titled debut is a mix of sighing shoegaze, cinematic wanderlust, and gloomy riffage.

title: Murder for Hire 2
label: Bread Winners’ Association
description: Only four months after his exceptional major label debut Islah, Baton Rouge rapper Kevin Gates returns with a mixtape that plays like a compilation of B-sides or outtakes from the Islah sessions.

title: Kidsticks
label: Anti-
description: Written and produced in Los Angeles with Andrew Hung of Fuck Buttons, Beth Orton's latest is anxious, playful, and sounds little like anything the singer/songwriter has done before.

title: Mondo Alterado
label: Hippie Dance
description: The Mexican techno producer Rebolledo specializes in work that feels hollowed out and slightly creepy, with a sly streak of absurdist humor.

title: X-Communicate
label: Sub Pop
description: In her latest transformation, Kristin Welchez leaves behind Dee Dee and the Dum Dum Girls for new alter ego Kristin Kontrol, foregoing DDG's garage-band cool for sleek synth pop.

title: Tempo
label: One Little Indian
description: Composer Olga Bell's Tempo resembles dance music as glimpsed through a funhouse mirror: strangely distorted, sometimes goofy, and deeply pleasing on a simple, almost childlike level.

title: The Dream is Over
label: SideOneDummy
description: PUP's second album is a glorious half-hour of redlining guitars and pile-on group chants that turn self-loathing and self-deprecation into a sort of superpower.

title: K.M.T.
label: Soul Jazz
description: Whether as the Sun God, I.B.M., IAMTHATIAM, or most often as Hieroglyphic Being, Jamal Moss' discography is filled u-turns; Africans With Mainframes swings into Chicago acid house at its most caustic.

title: Faraway Reach
label: Innovative Leisure
description: On their latest, tropical-house duo Classixx enlist guest vocalists from How to Dress Well to Passion Pit's Michael Angelakos to T-Pain.

title: It Happened in Flatbush
label: self-released
description: It Happened in Flatbush is a flat album in every way, filled with mealy-mouthed hooks and uninspired tropes—a spiritless effort from a NYC rap group that initially seemed novel in a post-TDE scene.

title: Goodness
label: Tiny Engines
description: On their latter-day emo classic Home, Like NoPlace Is There, the Hotelier took excruciating stock of the darkness. On their newest, the band is pushing with white-hot intensity toward the light.

title: The Last Word on First Blues
label: Omnivore
description: Producer Pat Thomas's loving Last Word on *First Blues *reissue reveals Allen Ginsberg as a missing link in the East Village's musical pathways, a secret alt-folk hero hidden in relatively plain view.

title: Ere Gobez
label: FPE
description: The Ethiopian 11-piece band's sophomore effort is a big, brave roar of an album, reaching and surpassing the heights of their excellent 2012 self-titled debut.

title: Earrings Off!
label: Tri Angle
description: The British experimental rock group Adult Jazz tackle themes of gender and the body's changing place in society on their sophomore outing.

title: Wake Up You!: The Rise & Fall of Nigerian Rock 1972-1977
label: Now Again
description: Wake Up You! specifically covers the short-lived but influential period of Nigerian rock in the country’s post-Civil War era (after 1970).

title: EP 4
label: Wolf Parade Productions
description: On their first EP of new material in six years, Wolf Parade aren't asserting themselves to the world so much as reintroducing themselves to each other.

title: Four Organs / Phase Patterns
label: Superior Viaduct
description: Four Organs and Phase Patterns come from a time when minimalist composer Steve Reich was in an obsessively scientific mode. They establish a new language, while arguing for their very right to exist.

title: Good Luck and Do Your Best
label: City Slang
description: Gold Panda's warm and exuberant new album sounds quite unlike any of the electronic music being made in 2016, and is refreshingly unfashionable in that way.

title: Dangerous Woman
label: Republic
description: Ariana Grande’s third album finds the 22-year-old pop star embracing a Sasha Fierce-like alter ego, with the help of Future, Nicki Minaj, Lil Wayne, Macy Gray, and others.

title: Put the Kid on the Sleepy Horse
label: Topshelf
description: Cult favorites Mock Orange return with an eighth album that reconciles their later alt-country leanings with their Midwestern emo roots.

title: Infrared
label: Fade to Mind
description: On her split EP with the producer Kingdom, Dawn Richard offers a diorama for love’s life cycle, encompassing everything from death defying adoration and righteous anger to, best of all, forgiveness.

title: Changesonebowie
label: Parlophone
description: The original David Bowie hits compilation tells the story of Bowie's metamorphosis from quizzical folkie to a conquering colossus, and is partially responsible for cementing his stardom.

title: Juarez
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: An outlier on the outlaw country scene of the 1970s, Terry Allen's Juarez is a bawdy song cycle that alludes to the fall of the Aztec Empire, Jesus, and motel sex. It retains its kick 40 years on.

title: Kamikaze
label: Votiv
description: The latest record from the So So Glos is driven by the tension between the band’s perennially youthful sound and their ever-more-jaded worldview.

title: Wave
label: Dial
description: The German musician Christian Naujoks makes pensive, idiosyncratic pieces somewhere between electronic and chamber music, and his new album is his most exquisitely melancholy work yet.

title: The Triad
label: Rough Trade
description: The Triad, Pantha du Prince’s first solo record in six years, is the producer's most maximalist and emotional release to date.

title: Pythagorean Dream
label: Foom
description: The pioneering composer and guitarist's latest album *Pythagorean Dream *is a simultaneously giddy and calm mix of the high-minded and the lizard-brained.

title: Fallen Angels
label: Columbia
description: Following on last year's Frank Sinatra tribute Shadows in the Night, Dylan's latest finds him once again putting his own idiosyncratic spin on a set of standards.

title: Ullages
label: Partisan
description: Their debut LP vented disillusionment with hard-charging punk and shouted choruses, but on their followup, the Leeds band channel their misery through a soft-focus dream-pop shimmer.

title: Andando el Tiempo
label: ECM
description: At 80 years old, Carla Bley remains a vital force as a pianist, composer, and improviser, mixing knowingly wry moments with a sense of mystery.

title: Strangers
label: Sacred Bones
description: On her latest gothic folk missive, singer/songwriter Marissa Nadler opens up her sound slightly, retaining her grey-skies aesthetic while bringing in a more spacious and rock-oriented sound.

title: These People
label: Cooking Vinyl
description: The former Verve frontman returns after a hiatus with another Richard Ashcroft solo album, with all the ostentatious orchestration, bumper-sticker mantras, and cursory electro-dabbling those entail.

title: Beyond the Bloodhounds
label: Canvasback / Atlantic
description: Through muscular, chugging guitars and plodding percussion, Nashville's Adia Victoria explores ugly emotional realities with "take it or leave it" boldness.

title: Teens of Denial
label: Matador
description: On Car Seat Headrest's first proper new album for Matador, frontman Will Toledo reaffirms that he is ahead of the pack as an imaginative singer-songwriter, capable of crafting dynamic indie rock.

title: A New Wave of Violence
label: Vice
description: Head Wound City, a supergroup drawing from members of the Blood Brothers, the Locust and the Yeah Yeah Yeahs, convene for an album of abrasive, low-stakes hardcore.

title: In Glendale
label: Rado
description: Tim Heidecker (of Tim & Eric) has released a slick rock record that is also a comedy album, and it is full of all the nervous laughs and queasy vibes of his surrealist comedy.

title: Skip a Sinking Stone
label: Mom & Pop
description: Mutual Benefit's Skip a Sinking Stone, a gorgeous collection of orchestral folk, focuses on the carefully plotted tours of a newly successful band and frontman Jordan Lee's adopted home of New York.

title: Day of the Dead
label: 4AD
description: This epic compilation produced by the National’s Bryce and Aaron Dessner serves as both a fine showcase of the Dead's iconic songs and a who's who of current indie rock.

title: Union and Return
label: Mexican Summer
description: A composer or a jokester? On his fourth album, Luke Wyatt's Torn Hawk project begins to emerge as the medium for a musician interested in pushing the limits of both.

title: Cut and Paste
label: Wichita
description: On his hooky, appealing debut album, the young Londoner Oscar Scheller makes blown-out indie jams with magnetic melodies and an obvious British lineage.

title: Tired of Tomorrow
label: Relapse
description: The Philadelphia band Nothing make gentle-sounding, springtime shoegaze with an alt-pop tinge that would seem all at odds with their gritty punk and hardcore pasts—until you listen to the lyrics.

title: Pile
label: Merge
description: Everything on the surface of A Giant Dog's Merge debut screams beware. From the violent lyrics to the grotesque cover art to the very name of the band, the message is clear.

title: Oh No
label: Hyperdub
description: Jessy Lanza's latest is a gorgeous and deadly pop music manifesto, full of pent-up nervous energy set to release.

title: What Follows
label: DFA
description: DFA vets Shit Robot return, and make their case as the label's long-underrated house band. Featuring guest spots from Alex Taylor, Nancy Whang, and the Juan Maclean.

title: Coloring Book
label: Unknown
description: Chance the Rapper's Coloring Book is one of the strongest rap albums released this year, an uplifting mix of spiritual and grounded that even an atheist can catch the Spirit to.

title: Happy Songs for Happy Zombies
label: Club AC30
description: Frequently pointed to as an underrated shoegaze gem, the debut EP by Pinkshinyultrablast provides an enjoyable (if brief) introduction to the band’s rapturous take on rock.

title: Full of It
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: Recent Kill Rock Stars signees Summer Cannibals expertly balance flame-belching Mad Max riffage with lyrics frankly exploring questions of codependence and need.

title: Fool
label: Brainfeeder
description: Fool is a playfully left-field electronic-jazz hybrid from Dutch artist Mitchel Van Dinther. It bursts at the seams with ideas, and at its best recalls the free spirit of late '90s electronic music.

title: I Hear You
label: Sub Pop
description: The Georgia post-punk band Arbor Labor Union are veterans of various punk and hardcore bands, and on their new album they expand on the rootsy drone of their first.

title: Holy Ghost
label: Run for Cover
description: Modern Baseball's Holy Ghost asks for difficult things out of its audience—space, patience and acceptance—but demonstrates them as a band with an undeniable sonic ambition and social conscience.

title: The Complete Prestige 10-Inch LP Collection
label: Prestige
description: The Complete Prestige 10-Inch LP Collection finds Miles Davis on a search for self, a search for a sound, a search for an aesthetic, a search for like minds.

title: Venus on Edge
label: Daps
description: On their fourth album, Hooded Fang slip away from their garage rock and indie-pop pasts and embrace a weirder, more wired sci-fi horror vision.

title: Nattesferd
label: Roadrunner
description: The Norwegian metal band Kvelertak find the unlikely meeting spot between black metal blast beats and the anthemic power of Van Halen and Judas Priest.

title: Bloom Forever
label: Stolen Recordings
description: In 2014, Peaches Geldof was found dead at 25, the result of a heroin overdose. After a few lost months, her husband Thomas Cohen finished a '70s singer/songwriter record about his wife and children.

title: Konnichiwa
label: Boy Better Know
description: On Skepta's long-awaited new album, the grime pioneer is full of sneering contempt for popular culture’s industry of image, the press, the police, and the government at large.

title: The Heart Speaks in Whispers
label: Virgin
description: Corinne Bailey Rae's lush new album features Esperanza Spalding, Moses Sumney, R&B group KING, and others. The mood feels wide open, centered on spacious grooves.

title: Under the Sun
label: Warp
description: UK producer Mark Pritchard's Under the Sun is deeply atmospheric and richly impressionistic. Key vocal features from Thom Yorke, Linda Perhacs, Bibio, and others give the album its sense of movement.

label: XL
description: The excellent debut of Soundcloud superstar Kaytranada features many collaborators (Syd! Anderson .Paak!) and many drums. He excels at chopping samples, but his colorful sound is never derivative.

title: Down in Heaven
label: Grand Jury
description: The Chicago rock band turns in a casual, charmingly low-key set of kitchen-table blues, slow-dance serenades, and unplugged power pop.

label: Big Crown
description: Covering 50 Cent, Cat Stevens, Faith Evans, and more on steelpan drums should not sound this gimmick-less. It helps that the Bacao Rhythm & Steel Band is, first and foremost, a strong funk ensemble.

title: Bottomless Pit
label: Harvest
description: On their new album Bottomless Pit, Death Grips stitch together one of their most cohesive grotesques, renewing their focus on songcraft.

title: Get Gone
label: Fat Possum
description: In their mix of soulful grease and punky grit, Seratones feel like a natural, rollicking complement to The Alabama Shakes.

title: Electronica 2: The Heart of Noise
label: Columbia
description: Electronic music pioneer Jean-Michel Jarre's latest album features guest spots from The Pet Shop Boys, Primal Scream, Cyndi Lauper, and...Edward Snowden.

title: Get In
label: Editions Mego
description: Austrian producer and Mego labelhead Peter Rehberg is a pioneer of laptop music that's at turns abrasive and sublime. His first release as Pita since 2004 is defined by shifts in volume and intensity.

title: A Moon Shaped Pool
label: XL
description: With their ninth studio album, Radiohead move beyond the existential angst that made them music’s preeminent doomsayers, pursuing a more personal—and eternal—form of enlightenment.

title: The Things That We Are Made Of
label: Lambent Light
description: Mary Chapin Carpenter's lean and haunting songs often sound best when they're given room to breathe. The production here by David Cobb (Jason Isbell, Sturgill Simpson) is just the ticket.

title: Spiritual Songs for Lovers to Sing
label: Mute
description: Former WU LYF frontman Ellery Roberts returns with LUH, his new project with visual artist Ebony Hoorn. Produced by the Haxan Cloak, their debut is a vast, swaggering colossus.

title: Take Me to the Alley
label: Blue Note
description: Grammy winning jazz singer Gregory Porter shone on the Disclosure single, "Holding On." But he's got a big career of his own outside of the British brothers. His new album is sweet and serene.

title: Cult Following
label: Merge
